history.content:
It's like breadth vs. depth. 168 is more "breadth". You don't go that much in depth regarding any specific topic: as long as you understand the main idea, you'll do fine in this class. 168 is also more project-heavy. 122 goes much more in depth regarding actual mathematical algorithms behind networking (for instance, queueing theory is covered much more in depth in 122). This is where the "depth" comes in. If you're interested in practical applications of networking, wait to take 168. If you want to learn a lot more about the algorithms and math behind networking concepts, take 122.

Parekh (who teaches 122) and Shenker (who teaches 168) are both well versed in the subject, but I'd say Parekh is a bit more approachable and friendlier compared to Shenker. You really can't go wrong with either of them though.

It also goes to say though that if you've taken one of the courses, taking the other one might be a waste of your time...

(source: I was in 122 for a month last semester - dropped it because of other time commitments - and I'm in 168 now)

children.subject: what were the assignments like in ee122? I'm ok with doing problem sets and programming assignments, but I'd loathe to do anything hands on with wires and circuits.

history.content: I didn't have the opportunity to take 168 this semester (conflicted with another class) and next semester will be my last. Does anyone know what EE122 is like compared to 168? I know its more "hardware" focused but what does that exactly mean. Also, what are the assignments in EE122 like? Programming, working hands on with circuits, problem sets etc? I know 168 is mainly python programming projects, so I'm wondering how that's different in 122. Thanks!
history.subject: EE122 vs cs168
